#Text=Čakr-paša

#Text=Mladen Stojanović ( Serbian Cyrillic : Младен Стојановић ; died 1885 ) , known as Čakr-paša ( Чакр-паша ) , was a Serb hajduk ( brigand and rebel ) leader mostly active in the Ottoman territories of the Pčinja region and in the Kumanovo district , one of the most notable hajduks in the second half of the 19th century .

#Text=A brigand since his teens , Čakr-paša deserted his guard service at the Serbian – Ottoman border in 1878 and became infamous in the following years for killing Ottoman officials , and also exploiting locals .

#Text=Having survived the Serbian – Ottoman War ( 1876 – 78 ) , Kumanovo Uprising ( 1878 ) and Brsjak Revolt ( 1880 – 81 ) , his end came in 1885 , after years on the run ( and wanted list ) from both Ottoman soldiers and gendarmerie , and Serbian border guards , when his comrade slit his throat .
#Text=After his death there were local stories of him as a fearless , stone-cold and raw individual , and also epic poems holding him a brave and sly hero .
#Text=Early life
#Text=Stojanović was born in Gornji Stajevac near Vranje ( modern Serbia ) . [ 1 ]
#Text=His father was Stojan ( hence the surname ) , and Mladen had two brothers , older Stevan and younger Anđel , and lived in the mahala ( neighbourhood ) of Meteževci . [ 2 ]
#Text=His paternal family , called Čekrci ( from čekrk , " winch " , as the ancestors were weavers ) , hailed from nearby Nova Brezovica . [ 2 ]
#Text=While his brother Stevan was an agriculturalist , living peacefully , Mladen and Anđel became hajduks . [ 2 ]

#Text=Already in his teens , it is said , Mladen came into conflict with the Ottoman government and was imprisoned at Vranje , only to be released after his mother begged to have him freed on a Christian feast day . [ 2 ] Mladen , nicknamed Čakr-paša , was an active hajduk in the Pčinja region ( on the Kozjak and German mountains ) prior to 1876 . [ 3 ]
#Text=Hajduk

#Text=He was captured by the Ottomans in 1876 ( before the war [ 2 ] ) and imprisoned in the Niš Fortress , from where the Serbian army freed him ( in 1877 [ 2 ] ) ; he joined the army as a volunteer in the Serbian – Ottoman War ( 1876 – 78 ) . [ 4 ]
#Text=While a volunteer , he befriended Veljan Strnovski and Jaćim Čelopečki . [ 5 ]

#Text=After the war , he was briefly , for a couple of months , a pandur ( policeman ) or guard in Vranje , but saw it as humiliating and crossed the Serbian – Ottoman border and returned to brigandage . [ 2 ] After 1878 , he was active in the frontier regions . [ 4 ]
#Text=View of the Prohor Pčinjski Monastery on the slopes of the Kozjak mountain , where Čakr-paša and his band was active .
#Text=Čakr-paša led for a time a band of 12 hajduks , among whom were his brother Anđel , Toša Šestoprst , Peša , Toma , and others . [ 2 ]
#Text=He was mostly active in the Ottoman territories of the Pčinja region and in the Kumanovo district . [ 2 ]
#Text=He attacked nizami ( regular soldiers ) , border guards , tax collectors , customs officers , aghas and beys . [ 1 ] Čakr-paša killed the seymens of Jusen Ferov near Prohor Pčinjski . [ 6 ]
#Text=He participated in the Kumanovo Uprising ( 1878 ) . [ 7 ]

#Text=After the suppression of the Kumanovo Uprising , the rebels that had fled to Vranje soon again began to cross Kozjak and German into the villages of Pčinja , where they would await Turks and Albanians in the dark . [ 8 ]

#Text=Among notable leaders that did this were Jaćim Jovanović , Čakr-paša , Vukadin Milkinski , Kuzman Petković , and others from the Poreče and Kičevo regions . [ 8 ] Čakr-paša would cross into Serbia and move in the spring part of the Banjska reka . [ 1 ]
#Text=He was among the 65 signatories of the 1880 appeal to Serbia to aid in a rebellion in Macedonia . [ 9 ]
#Text=He participated in the Brsjak Revolt ( 1880 – 81 ) . [ 5 ]
#Text=In springtime 1881 , in the Devet Jugovića -inn in Vranje , Micko Krstić assembled a band of 13 fighters , friends , blood-brothers and followers , and left Serbia . [ 10 ]
#Text=One of the members were Čakr-paša . [ 5 ]
#Text=Their first trainer and leader was Čerkez Ilija . [ 10 ]
#Text=In April 1881 , the bands of Čerkez Ilija and Micko were surrounded near Kriva Palanka . [ 5 ]
#Text=The bands were devastated by a force of Ottoman soldiers and Albanians , with Čerkez Ilija and his band all dead , Micko and the survivors fled for safety . [ 5 ]
#Text=In the fight , half of Micko 's band fell . [ 10 ]
#Text=Micko and the survivors crossed the mountains heading to Poreče , [ 10 ] while Čakr-paša stayed on the Kozjak . [ 5 ]
#Text=As the Ottoman government and nizami became impatient , [ 4 ] the Porte protested in Belgrade . [ 11 ]

#Text=On the Porte 's request , [ 1 ] the Serbian government under Milan Piroćanac proclaimed him an outlaw ( renegade ) in 1882 , [ 4 ] and then at the end of the year likewise by the srez ( district ) captain in Vranje . [ 2 ]
